div.head: MS III Drawings
div.p: Hand: pencil. In order of their appearance in MS III, front to back, the drawings contained in this Red Book are as follows:

list.item: “Harry Going across the Sea in a Steamboat,” [“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2] (1r);
“Picture of the Bristol Channel,” [“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2] (p. 15);
Ship and House, [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS III] (p. ?);
“Ragland Castle When Newly Built,” [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS III] (p. 34);

div.p: The first four drawings, which fall within “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, relate to the narrative more closely than do most of the “plates” for “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1. Whereas only one or two of the latter plates connect directly to the surrounding story, most of the MS III drawings for “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, pertain at least to the narrativeʼs general theme of travel. The subject of the drawing of Charlesʼs Wain, [“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2] is referenced directly in the narrative. These are the “copper plates” announced on Ruskinʼs title page for “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2.

Ruskin left a pencil notation for “chap. 6” on p. 36, and for “chap. 7” on p. 42. Although “Harry and Lucy” ends on p. 21, these possible projected chapter headings suggest that the miscellaneous drawings on pp. ?, 34, 37, and 43 may originally have been meant to illustrate the narrative. For example, ???, [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS III], which divides the text of “Of rocks first and of caverns now I sing” (the poem falling on pp. 36 and 38, and the drawing on p. 37), appears more likely linked to the notation “chap. 6” than to the poem. Similarly, Ship and House, [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS III] is wrapped round by “Time: Blank Verse,” the second poem of the MS III Second Poetry Anthology, which bears no relation to the drawing. In MS I, as well, Ruskin probably drew his plates prior to fair‐copying and/or composing the text around them.

“Ragland Castle When Newly Built,” [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS III] relates more closely to Poetry Descriptive, which contains the poem “Ragland Castle,” than to “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, but the narrative refers to the Welsh journey that would have included this attraction.
The drawings exhibit noticeably greater skill than those in MS I.
